### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

See also: #14903

```powershell
# Create a temporary dir. to experiment in.
Push-Location -ErrorAction Stop ($tmpDir = New-Item -Force -Type Directory (Join-Path temp: $PID))

try {

  # Create a sample dir...
  $null = New-Item -Type Directory -Force Foo

  # Try to rename it:

  # OK without a trailing path separator in the (positionally implied) -NewName argument
  { Rename-Item -ea Stop  Foo/ Bar } | Should -Not -Throw

  # !! FAILS, due to the trailing path separator in the -NewName argument
  { Rename-Item Bar/ Baz/ }  | Should -Not -Throw

} finally {
  Pop-Location
  Remove-Item $tmpDir -Recurse
}
```



### Expected behavior

```console
Both tests should pass.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The 2nd test fails:


[...] Cannot rename the specified target, because it represents a path or device name. [...]
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.7
```

comments.body:
On second thought: given that `-NewName` is explicitly only a _name_, the current behavior makes sense.

That said, given that a _leading_ `.\` or `./` _is_ currently quietly accepted, one could argue that a _trailing_ path separator should be as well.

title: Rename-Item should accept (and ignore) a trailing path separator in the -NewName argument
